pros:
- The peers that I worked with were wonderful people
- Higher salary to start, but be aware that Steward does NOT give annual raises, what you're offered will likely be your salary for many years
cons:
Working here was a bait and switch. I was offered a strategic HR role working primarily with Employee/Labor relations. Quickly found out this is more of a HR admin role that supported 1300+ employees and 99% of my time was paper pushing (helping get offers out, processing all LOAs, comp adjustments in the CBA - which no one seemed to understand). There has been zero investment in HRIS you will be doing everything on paper and logging on excel.

The average tenure of a HR Advisor/Director working at a Steward hospital in the region was ~ 6 months. Whenever someone new would start, they would need to "fix" whatever mess was left previously. It's amazing this organization has been around for decades with no systems or processes in place.

review_title: Company could be great if it could overcome its senior management
pros: Great salary and benefits. Personally I am granted a lot of autonomy
cons:
Steward gets a lot of crap for being a for-profit which is unfounded. However, it does have some very serious management issues which inevitably trickle downward and result in across-the-board low employee morale, a sense that employees are not appreciated, and a huge disconnect between the work at the hospitals and corporate. Changes in policy are not well communicated, and senior management seems to operate without a long-term plan, meaning changes are frequent and arbitrary. There are some really interesting ideas here about how to change health care but unfortunately Steward seems to think it can implement its ideas by being a bully both to its own employees and to external parties with whom it should be developing relationships. 

There is also a serious lack of work-personal life boundaries here which begins with our CEO and again trickles down through senior management. Non-urgent manners are expected to take your immediate attention on weekends and evenings and no vacation is safe from calls from the boss. It's a very male-dominated, impulsive leadership environment which can be exhausting for anyone wanting a life outside the office or able to think long-term about business.

review_title: Don’t waste your time. Your worth more.
pros: If your a Nurse fresh out of school they will hire you. That’s all that works here anymore. No one else will stay.
cons: I have worked at this Hospital 14 yrs. When Steward took this place over it has destroyed our reputation with both Employees and Patient’s. This used to be the top Hospital in town and it makes me sick to see what has happened since Steward took it over. All the Employees are leaving including myself to the other Hospital in town. They do not pay what you are worth and expect you to do more work than your capable of doing with a skeleton crew because they have laid off so many people. The patient to Nurse ratio is 8-10 per Nurse. The pay is $21 for RN’s. And way less for for Maintenance and other skilled professions.  I used to love this Hospital with a passion as did everyone else that worked here before Steward came in and destroyed everything that we worked to build for years. Management is horrible with this Company..HORRIBLE!!!! You are nothing but a number to them. They talk down to you and disrespect you like I’ve never seen before. They are constantly shutting down departments that this Hospital was known for in this area like Heart Surgery, Cancer Treatment Center just to name a few. All the Dr’s refuse to work in this Hospital now and the census is down to nothing. 375 bed Hospital that is doing good to have a census of 75 now.  This Hospital will not last much longer just like the others Steward has shut down recently.

review_title: Long story short: Don't work here
pros: I used to tell people that the best thing about working for Steward was "the people." Management doesn't understand what they are doing, but at least at the end of the day you could work with your peers and get stuff done. Unfortunately, it seems that Steward isn't interested in retaining good talent, so I can no longer say that "the people" is a good reason to work at Steward.
cons: Ralpha de la Torre doesn't seem interested in working with anyone that isn't a "Yes-Man." He hates Information Technology (despite it's crucial role in becoming an ACO) and he has cycled out 3 CIOs in the past 3 years, the current one, Julie Berry, who was the former director over client support at Partners Healthcare (a mighty big jump to C-level), doesn't have a clue what she's doing, which means she will probably stay for a long time as long as she keeps nodding her head at RDLT. The rest of the management team is about the same, Justine Carr does seem genuinely concerned for the quality of patient care, she may be the only good thing at Steward. Sadly, patients don't know any better, so they will probably keep going to Steward hospitals and visiting their Steward affiliated physicians. My only hope is that a better health care company buys Steward and does a rip and replace on the entire management team at 500 Boylston.

job_title: Medical Social Worker in Boston, MA
pros: The pay and benefits are very good, and affordable. The premium health insurance option is quite expensive given the sector, but it seems to be a good value. Fidelity for 401k, all sorts of health insurances, free short term disability insurance and AD&D, with optional supplements. And generally speaking, the work here is worth doing. People need help, and you can help them to some degree (and not go broke doing it)
cons: A great deal of pressure from corporate to make faster discharges, sign notes, and overcome barriers among other things. There seems to be little substantive filtering of this information to people on the ground, and it's from a very nursing driven perspective. In general, it seems like people here do not like Steward, or even their direct supervisor. Little to no opportunity for growth into a higher position as a social worker here. 2 weekend days a month are required for social workers, but you get a weekday off in exchange. You get a little extra money for the trouble. I would call this a benefit but I know for some this is a negative.

pros:
I loved my coworkers, everyone in the hospitals were so great. Sure sometimes we had bad days, but overall everyone was there to help the patients. Everyone was dedicated.

The benefits were good, one of the best benefits of working for a health care company is that your benefits are pretty good. Don't confuse benefits with compensation - compensation was average, they could have paid a little better but health care as a whole tends to pay non-providers less.
cons:
Corporate is another story entirely. Dr. Ralph de la Torre does not support the IT department, it's why the company is on it's 4th CIO in just 3 years. Of course, the new CIOs bring in their own people, sometimes the people are quite incompetent. The "Peter Principle" is in full effect here. 

The corporate offices resemble morgues, the people who work there are clearly unhappy and would rather be elsewhere. Westwood is the "red-headed stepchild" of the corporate offices, and Boylston is a fairy tale land where everyone wears a fake smile and keeps quiet when RDLT is in the office. 

The turnover is very high and the caliber of employees overall has gone down. It seems they would rather hire stupid people who don't question things than hiring people who could make a difference. If you are a good "kiss up" then this is the place for you. If you want a career where you can succeed by doing great things, find a job elsewhere.

review_title: Boston Globe, DPH, DMH is anyone listening?
pros: Company is investing in redecorating the inside and outside of the hospital(s).
cons: No raises,  poor leadership, no empathy for employees, poor patient care, no investment in staff education, multiple mistakes with pay checks.  A drawer full of pay checks over six months were not sent out, because the company was too cheap to pay for postage. Many are paychecks for some employees who also serve the military and are on their tours of duty, and not being sent their paychecks. Mental Health treatment in the ER is alarming, with very young children and psychotic adults placed in one behavioral health hallway. Where is DMH and DPH? Why is this allowed to happen?  Sooner or later someone is going to get hurt and it will be a patient.  Patients and staff  in mental health at risk; nurses complain but nothing happens.  Each week it gets worse, is anyone listening?  One nurse stated she had been billed twice for her medical coverage  because she worked at two hospitals Morton and Norwood. Shift differential errors, with the excuse that we all got moved over to corporate and we are trying to fix it, but we really don't know if we can.  Really?  Why did the payroll errors happen in the first place and will the pay be retroactive?  What do you mean you don't know if this can be corrected?  Isn't that stealing?  How can your shift differential be cut?  Huh.

review_title: Hostile disorganized senior management in Dedham
pros: No comment, too toxic to even describe
cons: Seems like a good culture. But once you get in the door, it's a completely different experience. Be ready to do the job of 3, and if you speak up, be prepared to be ostracized and bullied into the work by toxic, passive-aggressive senior managers. Employees fear the top people and are afraid to speak up; turnover is tremendously high. Many quit or get fired in the first few months. Constant vague expectations of the work. Lack of organization amongst senior management which leads to micromanagement of employees. Most people are scrambling constantly to beat the clock because they're buried in mounds of work. I have to take time every evening at home to work, taking time away from my children just to keep up on emails and the workload that's waiting in the morning. Bait & switch hiring tactics on what's promised in the job offer and what you really end up doing.

job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Mesa, AZ
pros: Sold to another company, Steward Health Care, taking over in October 2017. Finally, change is on the way!

For Profit!
Outdated equipment, short on supplies like IV pumps and additional staff. 
Management really does not have any relationship with their employees.  The pay rate is on the low end and raises are minimal. Education is lacking also, no real training. They like to hire a lot of new graduate nurses with no experience because they are cheaper than experienced nurses.  We work short staffed a lot.  There is no relationship of patient acuity to the number of patients you are assigned. Everything revolves around the bottom dollar. If you are looking for a career with advancement and training to better your self, this is not the place.  If you are a slacker and looking for a job where no one will notice, please apply and then wait about 3 months to get hired, while we continue to work short.

review_title: TAKE CAUTION BEFORE APPLYING at SEMC
pros: The pay is Amazing, one of the ONLY reasons I continue working here. Majority of the of Surgeons are also extremely competent and some of the staff actually care about patient care.
cons: We are UNDERSTAFFED and OVERWORKED in the OR. The turnover is horrible with hardly no retention at all. The only staff has been here forever or they are new and can not make the money SEMC offers at any other Hospital in the Boston area. We have an increase of surgical transfers from other facilities in the Steward system but DO NOT have the instrumentation or STAFF to really accommodate quality patient care. We are expected to take 24 hour weekend call which can also reflect poorly on patient care. We are short RN's and CST's. Last but not least the Cardiac staff and Surgeons are less than desirable and lack working as a team with the other Operating Room staff when we are extremely short staffed, especially the RN's.

job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant in Brighton, MA
pros:

-Wonderful, caring, compassionate nurses and aides
-Flexible scheduling
-Unionized workplace
-Shift differentials
-Amazing nurse educators, thorough training
cons:
-Under-staffing is a major problem right now, especially on day shifts (which are typically the busiest)

-Communication: this ties into the management issues; it is not easy to get in touch with upper management when problems arise

-Mgmt slow to resolve issues
-Frequent leaks with heavy rain; poor window insulation in patient rooms

review_title: Focus is money not patient care.
job_title: Family Nurse Practitioner in Brighton, MA
pros: Large medical center which is a teaching hospital for Tufts Medical School and several nursing schools in the area. Many resources for further education and training.  Journal clubs, large medical library, many research and outreach opportunities. Doctor's and midlevel colleagues are supportive and knowledgeable. There are several opportunities for advancement in a particular area.
cons:
Focus is on how much money hospital and practices can make with little focus on patient care.  Use a old fashioned cookie cutter model for all patient's. Staff and administration are generally not supportive of physicians, PA's, and NP's.  There is no sense of a medical team - it's more PCP'S and nurses vs. administration vs. other staff. Communication is the same and I often found that groups had difficulty communicating clearly with one another.  Ultimately this would affect patient care on a daily basis

Charts are often still in paper format despite having EMR in the office for over 2 years.  Even scanned paper charts in the EMR were often missing information creating a lot of extra work for staff and PCP's.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Port Arthur, TX
pros: Under Steward, I feel as though the employees are being held  accountable much more so than under Iasis.  It’s like someone blew the whistle on those accustomed to sitting in the stands and threw them in the game! They needed it!
cons:
We were pushed into Cerner with very little training, those they’ve contracted to help the merge are quasi-skilled in the program, at best and we are being taken away from those for whom we became nurses.  Can we alert our colleges to tack on some classes on computers in healthcare?  I clock more hours in front of a computer screen than an I.S. Tech!
On top of a terrible (but cheap for the company) computer charting system, charge nurses on the floors are taking a pt load with a census of 35+, no secretary and more times than not, no aides.  My 12 hour shift is 14+ so family time is out of the question. 
In a nut shell, change can be a good thing and I’m not afraid of it, but the implementation is haphazard. Cerner needs to be recalled and stream-lined (hopefully with a working nurse’s adaptation/input). I understand healthcare is a business and we (medical staff) are just a means to an end, but survey scores won’t improve if nursing’s hands are tied; Overwhelming and impractical.

pros: I learned SQL programming advanced Microsoft
cons: Management does not reward innovation

pros: Co workers, cheap health insurance, fabulous doctor at the practice I worked for
cons: Too many to list- RUN FAR AWAY!  Worst “management” I’ve ever encountered.  Manager is rarely at the practice though they collect a paycheck from funds allocated from the practice and productivity bonuses (the staff are completely overworked as a result of taking on WAY TOO MANY patients but are given nothing for the increased "productivity"), communication from her was non-existent and when discussions did occur the manager was unprofessional, threatening and distrustful.   I've never had such low self-esteem as an employee as I did working for this company and I vow to never allow myself to ever be in that situation again.  The company overall is all about the bottom line with blatant disregard for patient care and patient safety.  When you walk into any of the practices you can see staff are flustered, overwhelmed, overworked and overall unhappy.  The few good employees I've encountered have wisened up and left.  If you are thinking about working for this company you may as well turn yourself into a human punching bag and collect a meager paycheck instead.

review_title: They don't care about patients or employees ... at all
pros: Internal hospital teams are staffed with good people.
cons: Culture, values, CEO and executive leadership team (money motivated), anti-people senior HR leadership, poor benefits, 1.5% 401K match, low 1.5% (or non-existent) annual increases, poor pay (no budget for market adjustments), skeleton floor staffing,  terrible communication, very high turnover, no fringe benefits whatsoever, existing staff way overworked

pros: St. E's is in a great location, parking is cheap and convenient compared to the rest of Boston, many RNs have been there long-term, MNA union is a HUGE influence.
cons: Staffing is terrible (if it wasn't for the MNA, it would probably be even worse) and you can definitely see the impact this has on patient care. RNs are constantly being made aware that Press Ganey scores aren't as high as they should be, while at the same time being given very little staff, resources or management support to help increase patient satisfaction and get the scores up. New ICU and ED, however most of the inpatient floors are extremely old and facilities are constantly needing to be fixed.

review_title: Decent Entry level job, a stepping stone so to speak
pros: This was the only hospital that doesn’t require healthcare experience for the Public Safety Officer job, good way to gain experience, the officers in my dept are good people. Security manager is a good guy.
cons: Pay way lower than what we’re worth for what we do(officers constantly injured and assaulted) and getting a tiny raise yearly, low staffing (2 officers on overnight? That’s a joke), Upper management(ie: managers above my manager) really need to check their attitudes, and stop looking down at us as “the help”. Sometimes I feel like a subhuman, management will straight out look away when walking by our office as if hoping we won’t try to communicate (except for Matt the VP, who always makes sure to say hello), and the big one is the fact that we’re always walking on eggshells wondering if they’re gonna decide to be cheaper and replace us with a private contractor.

review_title: Horribly inhumane, disorganized, extremely political, lack of values, no concern for patients, just craving for money.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Fall River, MA
pros: Very few positives.  They pay decently, but not everybody fairly.  If you play games, you can get ahead.  If you are honest and not cheating the system, you will not be rewarded.
cons: This company is chaotic.  The leadership is extremely incompetent and has not much background in medicine.  The only way they keep their jobs is by playing politics and sucking up to the leadership.  The sad thing is that so many people in MA go to Steward's hospitals for healthcare, but they are getting cheated and definitely not the best possible care.  Steward's business practices border on illegal, such as forcing patients to stay in the system even when their insurance lets them choose providers, not paying contractors for months, using defective IT that jeopardizes patient safety, etc.  It's not a surprise that this company is on the verge of bankruptcy and keeps losing money.

pros: The amenities at the office building were nice - Gym, common space, etc.
cons: Total false promises during recruiting process.  Zero flexibility to work remotely.  Constant changing of policies, holidays being taken away.  Zero visibility from CEO or anyone in the c-suite.  The CEO is so incredibly paranoid about someone coming into the building to assault him, he has the c-suite area locked down like Ft. Knox.  Constant drama and in-fighting between the administrative staff, acting like high-school girls with no action from management to stop it.  Micromanagement from other direct managers, who would actually have you role play how to do your job.  Never in my life have I ever had anyone question my competency so much that they needed me to role play.  Very cold and sterile environment.  Steward is out to only make money and has no regard for any of their employees.  Definitely would not recommend working here.

They competed, rather than work together, so much animosity. I worked for Scheduling Solutions, which is part of JVMC, which was part of IASIS Healthcare, and is now Steward Healthcare. job_title: Certified Medical Assistant in New Bedford, MA

job_title: RN Case Manager in Dedham, MA
pros: My coworkers who attempt to please management, no matter how hard they are pushed. The staff recognizes the importance of quality care, the management no longer seems to care....very sad!
cons: New management has started in the last year, and the work environment has changed completely. We used to get regularly recognized for positive outcomes as a result of care provided. It's all about the bottom line.  As mentioned in another review, management is skirting on the edge of age discrimination when pushing out experienced nurses with unreasonable demands and extremely high caseloads, and replacing with LPNS, or staff with no experience and willing to accept a lower pay rate.

great way to develop your sense of humor (can't take it too seriously)

pros: There are no pros for this organization.  They will make decisions behind closed doors and not honor their initial representations.
cons: Steward's MO is to buy anything and everything in healthcare, and when their  poor and inept management fails, simply sell the hospital, close the office, or fire the employee with NO concern on how it affects the lives of their employees.  Management will lies, not pay bills, and be actively unethical to get their way.  I have heard stories of frankly dishonest behavior.  If it is called to their attention, the whistleblower if you will is fired.  There is no loyalty for hard work, excellent work, or concern for patients.  Steward will ruin healthcare in Boston.

cons: Management does not care about their employees.

pros:

cons:
The only positive outlook I have is going into work knowing that I have enough hours built up to call out each day. I mean, what’s a 2% raise when the company sold their assets fore billions. 

My ride to work includes me hoping I catch the flu from one of the failing hospitals they own, that or getting in a car accident on my lunch break and not having to go into the office.

review_title: STAY AWAY!! COULD NOT RECOMMEND THIS PLACE LESS!!

 most ignorant staff around (I try saying hello and good morning to everybody and people just look at you like you're insane. I'm very social and friendly).

review_title: Great potential, where company works to balance customer care, employee needs, and profitability to shareholders.

cons: There is a lot of change required.  While many processes exist, documentation is thin making repetition harder.  Not much communication from organizational leadership downward on organizational direction.

pros: Great bunch of dedicated RN's at Merrimack Valley.
cons: Unsafe staffing continues at Steward. As a nurse I am sad for the patients who enter these doors. We staff the hospital like a Monday through Friday business. I love my job but dislike administration running the hospital who looks at the all might dollar and not the patient.. Patients come first in my book I am a dedicated RN.

pros: Highly demanding setting with little downtime but constant projects and initiatives keep things fresh. High exposure to multiple areas of the system which allows for good education for an entry level employee.
cons: Little room for growth and promises made about advancement that are never realized. Most requests come from upper management and little credit is given to those who do the real work. High turnover due to overworking of staff.

pros:
Health benefits
Parking is affordable for Boston
Competitive pay 
Dunkin donuts!
cons: I could spend paragraphs here but the bottom line is this company is not patient or employee focused. As a nurse you see first hand what "light" staffing can do to patient care and it is not safe or inviting to patients or employees alike. Never was there a day that someone wasn't complaining about the facility in some way.  If you are new you are worked to the point where your only option is to leave because unless you were there for 10 years forget even getting a vacation.

job_title: Per Diem RN in Brockton, MA

Owned by Steward Health Care, a For Profit Company.  All too evident the dollar is the bottom line. Staff threatened too often to keep budget down or lay offs....Because it is unionized, regular staff paid well, but Per diem not part of the union..substantially lower pay than regular staff for experienced RN.  Regardless of experience, all per diem paid the same.  Good for new inexperienced RNs, not experienced.
Steward Health Care so cheap, patient care is affected.

They often lay off middle management, especially if experienced and higher salary.

review_title: US Family Health Plan at Brighton Marine

review_title: If you are a physician, do no work here
pros: The daily staff with whom you work; they are the glue that holds this place together and they are not appreciated for it.
cons:
I was told by many people to NOT work at Steward.  I foolishly did not listen to them, instead believing that my assessment of a seemingly kind future boss made my experience different.  I was 100 percent wrong.  Please contemplate that for a moment: this is a horrible FOR PROFIT hospital for whom to work.  The vast majority of doctors in my dept last LESS than ONE YEAR.
There are too many to list.  But here's a start.
1.  They are understaffed and worse--they don't care, making the same mistakes and overworking docs to the point where no one stays.  When I say, "they don't care,"I mean, they do not care. I couldn't say this more plainly.  Past the plastic smiles and promises of work life balance and how your boss has two daughters and she is always home by 4.  It's outrageous the degree to which heads of departments outwardly lie in order to recruit good people.
2. No work life balance whatsoever--except for the heads of the departments. if you are an physician--good luck.  Expect to do your notes from home every evening. Expect your spouse to pick up the slack and expect your kids to have a semi-absentee parent.  This is pandemic--especially in primary care departments.
3.  Even Locum Tenems people cannot place people here
4.  No resources, but they turn a fabulous profit--in the hundreds of millions, but they have no docs, insufficient nursing staff and some of the premises are filthy and hazardous.  I assure you that they will not show you these parts of the hospital when you tour.  Whatever they offer you for salary, slice it by FORTY percent because you will work 8 to 8 everyday, plus free weekends several times per year and some weekends just to catch up on discharge summaries, etc.
5.  Things are so bad here, the staff ask you to please not leave when they get to know you, as if they would try to entice you within their own means if they could.  It's sad and morally repugnant

job_title: Medical Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Hard to think of even one
cons:
Horrible management, with way to many management positions that do nothing.  You get no answers from management and no help on how to get those answers. 
This is the only company I have ever worked for, and I have been in healthcare for over 20 years,  that allows favoritism amongst management and thier subordinates to the extent that it has been noticed and commented on by Patients. If you happen to be one of the chosen favorites you are allowed to do only the parts of you feel are your job, ahils someone else in the sams position is expected to do the full job description. 
If management or one of their group doesn't like you, life is nothing but hell for you!
 I've heard conversations between a manager and another employee about a coworker,  conversation about the coworker beinging written up or suspended, about personl details that should remain with management only.
The pay is low and the benefits do not in anyway compensate. There is no match for 401K which I've never seen in a company this size, I've worked in many of the larger companies in Utah .
My advise is unless you just need a stepping stone to a better place stay very very far away from this company!
Maybe the buy out buy Steward will do something to help this poorly run company. Here's hoping!
